section.title: Introduction
section.para: While Nexus is a capable repository management and collaboration platform without any plugin extensions, Sonatype has provide a way for developers to extend the feature set of Nexus by exposing a plugin API. This chapter is a brief survey of some of the plugins which are available for Nexus.

section.title: Installing Plugins
section.para: Nexus plugins are incredibly easy to install. All you need to do to install a Nexus plugin is to put the Plugin JAR file in \${NEXUS_HOME}/runtime/apps/nexus/lib. As long as the plugin JAR is in the classpath of Nexus, it will be loaded the next time Nexus starts.

section.title: Available Plugins
section.para: The following sections list some of the available plugins. Some of the plugins in this list are very simple, like the Google Analytics Plugin. Other plugins such as the Staging Suite and Procurement Suite are of sufficient complexity to deserve an entire chapter of documentation.

section.title: Nexus Staging Suite
section.para: The Nexus Staging Suite provides an organization with an easy way to deploy artifacts to a temporary staging repository prior to a full releases. Using the features in the Nexus Staging Suite, developers deploy to a hosted repository only to have the deployed artifacts intercepted by a staging profile and held in a temporary staging repository. Once artifacts have been deployed to a temporary staging repository, Nexus administrators, release engineers, and QA personnel can then validate and certify a set of staged artifact before they are either promoted to a hosted repository or discarded.
The Nexus Staging Suite is an essential tool for organizations that need to incorporate QA into the release cycle. For more information about the Nexus Staging Suite, see .

section.title: Nexus Procurement Suite
section.para: Many organizations want to have some control over the third-party dependencies used in a system. This could be for a number of reasons. Maybe an architecture groups wants to limit access to a set of approved frameworks, or maybe the product's legal team wants to make sure that the licenses of every open source library incorporated into a project has gone through some evaluation process. Whatever the reason, the Nexus Procurement Suite gives a Nexus Administrator some control over what artifacts are going to be made available from a proxied repository.

The Nexus Procurement Suite gives organizations some control over inbound, third-party Maven artifacts. If you need to control and specify which dependencies are allow in your organization, you should learn about the Maven Procurement Plugin introduced in .

section.title: LDAP Authentication
section.para: When an organization needs to integrate Nexus with LDAP, it can do so by installing the LDAP Authentication plugin. This plugin adds the necessary configuration panels and modifies the security subsystem of Nexus to delegate authentication and access control to an external LDAP server. You can configure Nexus roles to match roles for users in LDAP and use these roles to manage access to Nexus resources.

section.title: Google Analytics Plugin
section.para: The Google Analytics Plugin is a simple plugin that simply inserts the Google Analytics tracking code just before the closing body tag in the Nexus HTML. To configure the Google Analytics plugin, you will need to put your organization's Google Analytics Web Property ID in the \${SONATYPE_WORK}/nexus/conf/ga-tracking-id.txt file.
If the \${SONATYPE_WORK}/nexus/conf/ga-tracking-id.txt file contains the value "UA-16932923-9", then the Nexus markup should contain the following HTML just before the closing body tag:
